questions.text: What is the most common histopathological variety of endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common variety of endometrial cancer is adenocarcinoma.

The other varieties of endometrial cancer are squamous cell, clear cell, and serous. The most malignant varieties are clear cell carcinoma and papillary serous tumor.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).

Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia.

Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:

Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids.

Other options:

Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.

The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in the colposcopic biopsy of a patient with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.solution:
The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

Features of CIN:

  • Varying degree of dysplasia
  • Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Mitotic figures
  • Intact basement membrane.

questions.text: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following the delivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hard on massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus. Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding from the placental implantation site is not arrested.

GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition.

Risk factors for atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about myomatous erythrocytosis syndrome?

choices.text: It leads to development of fibroids
It causes decrease in red cell mass

questions.solution:
Myomatous erythrocytosis syndrome occurs in less than 0.5% of women with leiomyomas. 

Option A: It is seen in patients having preexisting fibroids.

Options C and D: It causes excessive erythropoietin production by the kidneys or by the leiomyomas themselves, leading to an increase in red cell mass. Red cell mass returns to normal after hysterectomy.

questions.text: The first manoeuvre for shoulder dystocia consists of:

choices.text: Forceful adduction by extension of legs on abdomen
Forceful adduction by flexion of legs on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by extending them on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by flexing them on abdomen

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Roberts manoeuvre is the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. It involves flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.

questions.text: A primigravida was diagnosed with a prolonged second stage of labor due to the fetus being in occipitoposterior position. The obstetrician decided to give a posterior mediolateral cut at the introitus to facilitate delivery. Which of the following instruments would she use for the same?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of prolonged second stage of labor can be managed by performing an episiotomy. In the given figure, the instrument marked as "D" corresponds to episiotomy scissors.

An episiotomy is done to prevent posterior extention leading to obstetric anal sphincteric injuries.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh-negative patient with an antibody titer of 1:32 presents to the clinic at 30 weeks. A USG reveals features of fetal edema, ascites, and polyhydramnios. Cordocentesis was done for fetal blood sampling. At what hematocrit value is intrauterine blood transfusion indicated?
questions.solution:
Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%.

The blood for transfusion is usually O negative and cross-matched with the mother's blood. It is highly packed to achieve a hematocrit of 75 -80%.

Intrauterine transfusions may be done intraperitoneally where blood is absorbed through diaphragmatic lymphatics. It may also be done intravascularly through the umbilical vein. The segments of the umbilical vein used are the intrahepatic portion or at its insertion into the placenta. 

Complications of intrauterine transfusion include:

  • Fetal demise
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Placental abruption
  • Pre-term labor
  • Bradycardia/tachyarrhythmia
  • Umbilical cord hematoma

questions.text: Which of the following changes are not seen in fibroids?
questions.solution:
Squamous metaplasia is not seen in fibroid. 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about fibroid uterus?

choices.text: Hyaline degeneration starts from the center
Calcareous degeneration starts from the periphery
Red degeneration is the most common degeneration
Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change

questions.solution:
Hyaline degeneration is the most common type of degeneration.

Option A: In a fibroid, blood vessels run from the periphery to the centre. Hence, the centre is the least vascular part and more prone to degeneration. Hyaline degeneration is most common. 

Option B: Calcareous degeneration starts from the periphery along the course of blood vessels. Calcium phosphate and carbonate are deposited, leading to a womb-stone appearance on radiology. 

Option C: Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change in fibroids, occurring in <0.5% patients.

questions.text: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7th day. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type of twin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins.

The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.

Monozygotic types Time of zygote division
Dichorionic diamniotic <72 hours
Monochorionic diamniotic (more common) 4-8 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic  8-12 days
Conjoined twins >12 days

Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses. They include:

  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin
  • Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS)

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the following complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female with endometritis did not complete the course of antibiotics she was prescribed. Following this, her infection failed to resolve and she developed a tubo-ovarian mass. How can this mass manifest?
  1. Tubo-ovarian cyst
  2. Hydrosalpinx
  3. Twisted ovarian cyst
  4. Chronic pyosalpinx
  5. Ruptured endometriotic cyst
questions.solution:
The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID points towards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovarian cyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx.

Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development of chronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which may manifest as:

  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Chronic pyosalpinx
  • Chronic interstitial salpingitis
  • Tubo-ovarian cyst
  • Tuberculous form

A twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiological change seen in pregnancy. 

Cardiovascular parameters that increase in pregnancy are:

  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Heart rate

Cardiovascular parameters that decrease in pregnancy are:

  • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
  • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
  • Mean arterial BP
  • Artery venous O2 gradient

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female sex worker presents with complaints of constipation and blood in stools for 3 months. On DRE, a circumferential constriction is felt beyond which the finger cannot be advanced. Which of the following is a probable cause for this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complication of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). 

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed and untreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs due to the contigu­ous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissue formation.

The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include:

  • Rectal stricture formation may lead to:
    • Intestinal obstruction
    • Rectovaginal fistulae
  • Proctitis
  • Vulvar cancer.

questions.text: A woman with urinary incontinence was diagnosed to have a vesicovaginal fistula. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Vesicovaginal fistulas are mostly acquired. 

In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas. 

Congenital genitourinary fistulas and fistulas resulting from infectious conditions are rare.

questions.text: What is the most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery is complete perineal tears.

In face to pubis delivery, the occiput is posterior, and therefore, the largest biparietal diameter (9.4 cm) distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter (8 cm). A liberal episiotomy helps to avoid perineal tears.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is the most potent drug to control PPH.

Though oxytocin is the most commonly used drug for the prevention and treatment of PPH, Carboprost is highly efficacious than oxytocin in treating PPH. If the question would have been "Drug of choice to treat PPH" then the answer will be Oxytocin. 

Drug

Use in PPH

Oxytocin

DOC to prevent and treat PPH

Methergin

Drug to prevent and treat PPH

Carboprost(PGF2)

Best drug to control PPH

Misoprostol(PGE1)

2nd line drug to treat PPH

Initially for PPH, oxytocin or methergin (ergometrine) is given. If it fails to control the bleeding then Misoprostol is given.

questions.text: A woman who was treated for complete hydatidiform mole decides to conceive again. The risk of developing trophoblastic disease in the subsequent pregnancy is _____
questions.solution:
The risk of recurrence of hydatidiform mole in subsequent pregnancies is 1-4%

The incidence of malignant sequelae is 15-20% following complete moles and 1-5% following partial moles.

Women with prior gestational trophoblastic disease or successfully treated neoplasia usually do not have impaired fertility, and their pregnancy outcomes are usually normal. Sonographic evaluation is recommended in early pregnancy, and subsequently if indicated. Women who undergo chemotherapy must be followed up for 1 year. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the β hCG levels.

At delivery, the placenta or products of conception are sent for pathological evaluation, and serum β-hCG level is measured 6 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: Dose of meperidine in postpartum period through patient controlled analgesia is______.

choices.text: 10 mg with a 6 min lockout interval
20 mg with a 6 min lockout interval
10 mg with a 10 min lockout interval
20 mg with a 10 min lockout interval

questions.solution:
Dose of meperidine in the postpartum period through patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) is 10 mg with a 6-min lockout interval.

PCA is a delivery system with which patients self-administer predetermined doses of analgesic medication to relieve their pain. All PCA modes contain the following variables:

  • Initial loading dose
  • Demand dose
  • Lockout interval (time interval before the pump can provide the next dose)
  • Background infusion rate 
  • 1-hour or 4-hour limits

Morphine is the most commonly used intravenous drug for PCA. The maximum dose is 200 mg in 4 hours. An additional 25 mg booster dose is permitted for a maximum of 2 doses.

The below image shows the PCA apparatus.

questions.text: All of the following are benefits of using a transverse abdominal incision for caesarean delivery in a patient except______.
questions.solution:
Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with polyhydramnios, presents to the clinic with respiratory distress at 38 weeks of gestation.  The obstetrician plans for induction of labor.  What is a safe method of induction in this patient?

choices.text: Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip

questions.solution:
Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip is a safe method for induction of labor in polyhydramnios.

Abdominal amniocentesis drains a good amount of liquor (amnioreduction), after which the oxytocin infusion can be started. This will minimize the sudden decompression and reduce the risk of placental separation, cord prolapse and change in lie of the fetus.

Although polyhydramnios does not constitute an absolute contraindication for the application of prostaglandins, these substances should be administered with caution. There is a marked increase in the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage and amniotic fluid embolism with their use. Hence, amnioreduction is a preferred mode of treatment in polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. He mentioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and ice cream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion. 

If anemia is diagnosed:

  • In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred
  • In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls <8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml
  • In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred

Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose.

Other iron preparations include:

  • Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate 
  • IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose
  • IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose
  • Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed for postpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.

Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).

It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding cholestasis of pregnancy?

choices.text: Pruritis preceeds abnormal lab values by weeks

questions.solution:
Serum bilirubin increases very late in the disease and total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 5 mg/dL. 

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment.

Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated but seldom exceed 250 U/L.

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: True regarding eclampsia

choices.text: Magpie trial is related to eclampsia
First line of management is thiopentone sodium

questions.solution: Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulphate lowers the risk of eclampsia. In a woman with preeclampsia, a convulsion that cannot be attributed to another cause is termed eclampsia. The seizures are generalized and may appear before, during, or after labor.

questions.text: What is the most common type of placental vascular anastomoses seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies?
questions.solution:
Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies. 

All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be:

  • Superficial artery-vein
  • Deep artery-vein
  • Artery-artery
  • Vein-vein
  • One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veins

These anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. When a pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like:

  • TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome
  • TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence
  • TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion

The most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of male infertility?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis.

Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is a contributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation.

Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion ≥5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible.

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple / extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim
  • Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: You have performed MTP on a multigravida at 10 weeks of gestation.  As a part of post-op advice, you must prescribe her a prophylactic antibiotic. Which of the following drugs would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the preferred drug for post-abortal antibiotic prophylaxis in this case. Oral doxycycline 100 mg is given 1 hour before surgical evacuation. 200 mg is given after the procedure is complete.

The best method of MTP at 7-12 weeks is by suction and evacuation. Following this procedure, antibiotic prophylaxis is given with doxycycline.

questions.text: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy. 

Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp. 

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Loin pain
  • Vomiting
  • Right-sided renal angle tenderness

Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia.

Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.

questions.text: During your OBG rotations, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you will use for the same.
questions.solution:
This is an image of a cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.

It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.

questions.text: An increase in which of the following is spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea attributed to?
questions.solution:
Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2α. This is secreted under the effect of progesterone.

Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatory cycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.
  • Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

 

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: What does fetal position refer to?

choices.text: Part of presentation which lies over the internal os
Relation of different parts of fetus to one another
Relation of the denominator to different quadrants of the pelvis
Part of fetus lying in the lower segment of uterus

questions.solution:
Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

Definition of various terminologies used for fetus in-utero:

Term: Definition:
Lie Relationship of the long axis of fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
Presentation Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
Presenting part

Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os
Attitude

The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
Denominator

An arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part which comes in relation with the various quadrants of the maternal pelvis
Position

Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis
Engagement

When the biparietal diameter has passed the plane of the pelvic brim, the head is said to be engaged.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with profuse, painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea and her UPT is negative. On ultrasound, endometrial thickness is 21mm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica. 

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding. It is characterized by continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhea. It is usually seen in the age group of 40-45 years. A history of menorrhagia may be present. 

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Option A: Senile endometritis occurs after menopause when the endometrium is thin and atrophic. It may be associated with accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity. 

Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow is present. 

Option D: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Progesterone intake is not a risk factor for preterm labour. Progesterone is used for prophylaxis of preterm labour.

Risk factors for preterm labour:

  • Maternal history -
    • Previous history of spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery
    • Artificial reproductive technique
    • Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTI
    • Smoking
    • Maternal stress
  • Pregnancy complications -
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Antepartum haemorrhage
    • PROM
    • Overdistended uterus - polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy
    • Cervical incompetence
    • Uterine malformations
    • Intrauterine death
  • Maternal chronic diseases -
    • Hypertension
    • Nephritis
    • Diabetes
    • Severe anaemia
    • Periodontal diseases

Option A: Multifetal pregnancies are common following artificial reproductive techniques and can be associated with preterm labour.

Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria or bacterial vaginosis can cause spontaneous preterm labour.

Option C: Chronic diseases like periodontal disease increase the risk of preterm labour.

questions.text: A couple with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse requires emergency contraception. Which of the following is not a mechanism by which these drugs act?

choices.text: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.solution:
Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are also called interceptives.

The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms.

Methods of emergency contraception:

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel

0.75mg stat and repeat dose after 12 hours or

1.5mg as a single dose
Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tabs stat and 2 tabs after 12 hours
RU486 (Mifepristone) Single dose of 25-50mg
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUDs Insertion within 5 days of intercourse
Centchroman

2 tabs(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval of 12 hours

Should be taken within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal 30 mg within 5 days of intercourse

questions.text: All of the following are non-molar trophoblastic neoplasms except _____.
questions.solution: Invasive mole is a molar trophoblastic neoplasm.

questions.text: You would suspect and evaluate for carcinoma cervix in patients presenting with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Patients with carcinoma cervix most commonly present with metrorrhagia, now known as intermenstrual bleeding.

Post-coital bleeding is the most specific symptom of carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding menorrhagia?

choices.text: Heavy and regularly timed episodes of bleeding
Amount of bleeding greater than 50 ml
Duration of bleeding greater than 5 days

questions.solution:
Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding.

Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>8 days). Nowadays, menorrhagia has been replaced by the term heavy menstrual bleeding. This is defined as greater than 80 mL per cycle, which will result in anemia if recurrent

Investigations done in case of menorrhagia:

  • Complete blood count (CBC) - to rule out anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Coagulation studies are ordered only in case of clinical suspicion and correlation with CBC
  • Sonohysterography/Hysteroscopy - to diagnose endometrial polyps and fibroids
  • Endometrial biopsy - in case of suspected endometrial hyperplasia
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - supplements biopsy

questions.text: According to WHO, a pregnant woman in her second trimester will be considered anemic if her hemoglobin is less than _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO, anemia in the second trimester is defined as hemoglobin <10.5 g/dL, while according to ICMR it is Hb <11 g/dL.

The normal physiologic range for hemoglobin during pregnancy is 11.5-13.0 g/dL. Anemia in pregnancy is said to occur when Hb level is <11 g/dL. It is classified as shown below:

Hemoglobin values (g/dL)  WHO classification of anemia in pregnancy ICMR classification of anemia in pregnancy
≥11

Normal *

 Normal
10-10.9

Mild 

 Mild
7-9.9  Moderate Moderate
<7  Severe Severe
<4   - Very severe

(*According to WHO, anemia in the second trimester of pregnancy is defined as Hb <10.5 g/dL).

Physiological anemia during pregnancy is anemia that is normally seen during pregnancy. This occurs due to the expansion of plasma volume by 30–40%. This increase is much more than the increase in red cell mass (20-30%) during pregnancy. This leads to hemodilution and an apparent decrease in hemoglobin levels.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with triplets on ultrasound. The obstetrician has planned to do a selective fetal reduction of one of the fetuses to improve the outcome of the pregnancy. What is the ideal timing and the method for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Selective fetal reduction is done between 10-13 weeks via intracardiac injection of KCl.

In multi-chorionic multifetal gestations, selective reduction of the smallest or anomalous fetus/fetuses is done to increase the chance of survival of the other fetuses. 

Laser ablation or bipolar coagulation of the umbilical cord of the targeted fetus is done. This protects the surviving fetuses from the adverse effects of the drug.

questions.text:
Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
1) Abdominal A) Spiegelberg
2) Cervical B) Studdiford
3) Cornual C) Rubin
4) Ovarian
questions.solution:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
Abdominal Studdiford
Cervical Rubin
Ovarian  Spiegelberg

Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.

Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.

Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

questions.text: When does puerperium begin?

choices.text: After the fourth stage of labour

questions.solution:
Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and lasts for approximately 6 weeks.

It is the period following childbirth during which body tissues revert back approximately to the pre-pregnant state, both anatomically and physiologically.

Puerperium can be divided as follows:

  • Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours
  • Early puerperium: up to 7 days
  • Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.

*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?

choices.text: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
It is homologous to scrotum in male
The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands

questions.solution:
The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora.

The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain:

  • Hair follicles
  • Sebaceous glands
  • Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands

The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis.

The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to glans penis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for estrogen therapy?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy (HRT). HRT can be initiated in patients with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking; provided they are regularly monitored.

Contraindications of estrogen therapy:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids - as the fibroids may enlarge in size.

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging diameter.

Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5cm.

Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. 

Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm. 

Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull at about 7.5 cm. However it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary site for gonococcal infection?
questions.solution:
Ectocervix and vagina are lined by squamous epithelium which is resistant to gonococcal infection.

The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium. Hence, gonococcus usually affects the following structures:

  • Endocervix
  • Urethra
  • Skene’s glands
  • Bartholin's glands.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters cannot be viewed in lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry?
questions.solution:
The bispinous diameter can be viewed in the anteroposterior view and not the lateral plate pelvimetry.

X-ray pelvimetry is done using 3 views:

  • Anteroposterior - Transverse diameter and bispinous diameter is determined.
  • Lateral - Obstetric conjugate, sacral curve and pelvic inclination are seen. 
  • Outlet - Outlet diameters are determined. 

Note: CT pelvimetry is preferred over X-ray pelvimetry due to the lower dose of radiation delivered. 

Given below are images of CT pelvimetry, anteroposterior and lateral views respectively. The marked diameters are as follows:

2 - Interspinous diameter

3 - Intertuberous diameter

4 - Obstetric conjugate

5 - Pelvic outlet

questions.text: When is the ideal time to repair old complete perineal tears which had occurred during delivery?
questions.solution:
In case of an old complete perineal tear, the optimum time for operative repair is after 3-6 months post-delivery.

The best time of repair is, however, within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, then the better option is to do it 3-6 months after delivery. By 3 months' time, the local infection subsides, the general condition of the patient improves and the baby can be kept at home. If kept for more than 6 months, there is more fibrosis on the margins and unnecessary prolonged inconvenience to the patient.

Perineal repair after an episiotomy or spontaneous obstetric laceration is one of the most common surgical procedures. Obstetric perineal lacerations are classified as first to fourth degree, depending on their depth.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a patient with ruptured ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A shock index of >0.85 is seen in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. There is massive blood loss (SBP<110 mmHg) sometimes leading to shock. 

The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.

Condition Range of shock index
Normal value of shock index (non-pregnant) 0.5 - 0.7
Normal value of shock index in pregnancy (i.e) obstetrical shock index 0.7 - 0.8
Significant or massive blood loss 0.9 - 1.1

Option A: Sub-diaphragmatic blood irritates the phrenic nerve. This causes a referred pain at the shoulder tip. This is called as Danforth sign.

Option B: The expulsion of decidua in a single piece through the cervix is called a decidual cast. This is due to the fall in the levels of β hCG and progesterone.

Option C: Vertigo and syncope are due to reflex vasomotor disturbances due to peritoneal irritation from hemoperitoneum.

questions.text: Which infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosa and the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage.

Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goes unnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications.

Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed early and causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection.

Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis and vaginitis.

questions.text: When does keratinization of fetal skin occur?
questions.solution: Keratinization of fetal skin occurs at 22–25 weeks. Therefore, diffusion across fetal skin does not occur after this period. So fetal plasma does not contribute to amniotic fluid formation after this time period.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with secondary syphilis. Which of the following would you not expect to see in this patient?

choices.text: Constitutional symptoms like fever, sore throat

questions.solution:
Painless indurated genital ulcers are not seen in secondary syphilis. They are a feature of primary syphilis.

The features of secondary syphilis are:

  • It occurs within 6 weeks to 8 weeks of the onset of the primary chancre.
  • Macular/roseolar rash is the earliest rash. It fades leaving hypopigmentation around the neck called leucoderma syphiliticum or necklace of Venus.
  • Papular rash involves the palms and soles.
  • In later stages, nummular lesions with scales resembling psoriasis. Due to the serous discharge of the lesions, the scales are easy to remove.
  • Papules on the oral mucosa, form grey oval patches and coalesce to form snail‐track ulcers as seen below, although ulceration is rare.
  • Condyloma lata is the classic finding. They are moist, well-demarcated papules and plaques which are seen on the genitalia. These are highly contagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area and upper thighs.
  • Syphilitic alopecia or moth‐eaten alopecia as seen below is a form of non-scarring patchy hair loss.
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy is also seen. Other systemic features of secondary syphilis include panuveitis, periostitis and joint effusions, glomerulonephritis, hepatitis, gastritis, and myocarditis.

The lesions of secondary syphilis resolve spontaneously in a variable time period and are followed by the stage of latent syphilis.

questions.text: Chorionic villus sampling was performed on a G2P1 Rh-negative woman at 10 weeks of gestation. What is the dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin that should be administered?
questions.solution:
The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 μg.

All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 μg of Rh-immune globulin IM in the first trimester in the following conditions:

  • Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion
  • Ectopic/molar pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling 

Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 μg. Generally, a 300 μg dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. 

The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 μg or 1500 international units (IU).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of menometrorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Menometrorrhagia refers to menstrual bleeding at frequent intervals.

Menometrorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleed­ing that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals. It can be caused by cervical cancer and granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: When does the sexual differentiation of the fetus occur?
questions.solution:
Sexual differentiation of the fetus occurs only after the 7th week of development. 

The chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm that fertilizes the ovum (X or Y). However, male and female morphological characteristics begin developing after the 7th week. At the end of the 6th week of development, it is impossible to distinguish between the two sexes.

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman is found to have an adnexal mass on evaluation. Above what risk of malignancy index (RMI) score is there a high risk of ovarian malignancy?
questions.solution:
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) score of 200 or more indicates a high risk for ovarian cancer in a patient with an adnexal mass. 

Risk of malignancy index (RMI) = U x M x CA125

  • U = Ultrasound score
    • The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites, and bilateral lesions.
    • U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0)
    • U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1)
    • U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5).
  • M = Menopausal status
    • M= 1 (for pre-menopausal)
    • M= 3 (for post-menopausal)
  • CA-125 = Serum CA-125 level (in IU/ml)

For any post-menopausal woman with an ovarian cyst of size >1cm, RMI should be calculated.

questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
questions.solution:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.

A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during:
questions.solution:
The quadruple screening test is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of gestation. The most accurate values are seen during 16-18 weeks of gestation. 

It is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG, and inhibin-A. 

In Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edward's syndrome (trisomy 18), quadruple-marker screenings do not provide any added benefit over first-trimester screenings. It is generally used as a stand-alone test if screening is done for the first time in the second trimester or if first-trimester screening is not available.

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect Trisomy 13/ Patau syndrome
MSAFP Low Low High  Normal
β hCG High Low Normal  Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal  Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal  High

questions.text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 

First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.

First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:

  • Insulin
  • Glyburide 
  • Metformin

questions.text: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.solution: The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5.

questions.text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele.

DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: A patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy is planned for medical management with methotrexate. What is the multi-dose protocol for this drug?
questions.solution:
In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injection on alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7.

This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Up to 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after 24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate.

MTX Protocol Multi-dose regimen Single-dose regimen
Dose 

1 mg/kg
(+ 0.1 mg/kg LEU)

50 mg/m2
(Body surface area)
Regimen Alternate daily doses  Day 0
hCG measurement Days 0, 1, 3, 5, 7 Days 0, 4, 7
Treatment success hCG declines >15% from the previous value hCG declines >15% between Day 4 and 7
When to administer additional dose   2nd, 3rd or 4th dose to be given if hCG does not decline 15% from the previous value. Maximum 4 doses   Second dose on Day 7 if hCG does not decline 15% 

 Note: If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labour. After delivery of the head, turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following can be used for the management of this patient?
  1. Mc Robert's maneuver
  2. Wood's corkscrew maneuver
  3. Modified Ritgen's maneuver
  4. Rubin's maneuver
  5. Pinard's maneuver
  6. Gaskin's maneuver
questions.solution:
A patient with gestational diabetes and the presence of turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Robert's manoeuvre, Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre, Gaskin's manoeuvre, and Rubin's manoeuvre are all used in its management. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis. Turtle sign may be seen which refers to the recoil of the fetal head against the perineum.

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre (flexion and abduction of thigh)
  • 2nd line of management - Rubin's (rotation of the easily accessible shoulder by 30-45°), Woods corkscrew manoeuvre (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a cork screw fashion) ; OR Gaskin (all four's position)
  • Last line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (head is rotated to its pre-restitution position and caesarian section is performed); OR procedures such as cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of the baby); symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.

questions.text: Radiological modalities of treatment of fibroid uterus include all except:
questions.solution:
TCRE is Trans cervical resection of endometrium which is not used in treatment of fibroid uterus.

Uterine Artery Embolization/Uterine Fibroid Embolization (UAE/UFE):

  • It is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis.
  • Because vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, sparing the surrounding myometrium.

Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound MRgFUS:

  • It is also called MR-guided high intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU).
  • Ultrasound energy is ocused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas.
  • Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperature feedback to limit surrounding thermal injury.

Uterine artery embolization:

MRgFus procedure:

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.

Grading of ovarian cancer:

  • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
  • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. 
  • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur. 

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine USG scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes?
questions.solution:
Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is ≥ 126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. 

A patient is said to have overt diabetes if:

  • Fasting blood sugar ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%

The maternal complication of diabetes:

  • increased Miscarriage and preterm labor.
  • increased incidence of preeclampsia
  • polyhydramnios
  • prolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvic disproportion.

Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes:

  • fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg)
  • congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.

questions.text: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. How much progesterone is released by this device?
questions.solution:
Progestasert releases 65 μg of progesterone/day.

Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs.

There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with overt diabetes comes to you for pre-conception counseling. Which of the following congenital heart defects are least likely to occur if she were to have a child?
questions.solution:
Tetrology of Fallot (TOF) is usually not seen in infants of diabetic mothers.

Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiac anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers.

Cardiac defects that present more often in infants of diabetic mothers are:

  • Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  • Double outlet right ventricle (DORV)
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Truncus arteriosus
  • Tricuspid atresia
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Most resources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them is more common.

questions.text: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth of coarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.

Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is ≥8. Moderate to severe hirsutism is present if the score is ≥15.

Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with secondary infertility following radiation therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma. You plan to test her ovarian reserve. Which of the following is the best indicator of this parameter?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the level of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is the best indicator of ovarian reserve.

Ovarian reserve is the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase on day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle.

A high FSH level indicates that the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are present in the ovary. FSH is high in ovarian hypofunction and postmenopausal women.

Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve. Unlike FSH, its levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle. AMH is produced by the granulosa cells in ovarian follicles. 

Note: Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptive pills and tobacco smoking.

questions.text: A P1A1 woman with a history of obstructed labor is being evaluated for a contracted pelvis. CT pelvis shows both sacral alae are absent. What is the type of pelvis seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of pelvis seen here is Robert's pelvis. In it, the pelvis is transversely contracted and the ala on both sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones.

Option A: In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum.

Option C: Kyphotic pelvis occurs secondary to the kyphotic changes of the vertebral column either following tuberculosis or rickets.

Option D: In rachitic pelvis, due to softening of bones, flattening of the pelvis occurs.
